ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned lots of yoruba and about the importance of enjoying learning

This course was an amazing introduction to the basics of the Yoruba language. I think it's biggest strengths were addressing the "why"'s of the language. Why do people say x? Why is y present in this sentence? I learned so much about the language that I think established a firm foundation to build upon in the future.
how to have conversation in yoruba about family, likes/dislikes, greetings, school/occupations, describing people, and more

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: prof Seye is the best ever. he's so funny and made class enjoyable every day. the bi-weekly quizzes were super helpful so that we didn't have to cram for the midterm and final
weaknesses: maybe a bit more exposure to the vocab. sometimes the role plays were repetitive.

Strengths are the professor's deep understanding of both the language and the students. It's not an anomaly if something in the language is unclear or confusing; he gets it.
Weaknesses: TA didn't do much.

strengths: comfortable environment to make mistakes and receive helpful feedback, kind and receptive instructor. I also like when we watched videos, but I wish we could watch videos that do not have english subtitles. that way, we can figure out what is being said based on images and context without relying too much on the english subtitles.

weaknesses: the language table requirement. since it met outside of scheduled class time, I usually had pre-scheduled commitments and couldn't make it. there was a makeup option at the end of the semester, but I wish I would have been able to go weekly. not sure what a solution would be to this if other people had the same issue.
the strength is that the teacher is a super cool guy. The weakness is that were essentially learning theoretical yoruba, not the yoruba that people actual speak.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES wholeheartedly. so much fun. would especially recommend it if you come from a Yoruba speaking family because it's so nice to finally be able to speak with your parents. we really learned a lot in one semester. I would even recommend to people who don't come from Yoruba speaking families! prof is very understanding and flexible
YESSSSS. It's a beautiful language with so much to learn about. To anyone in the Nigerian diaspora, it really comes in handy when impressing the aunties.
yes! I think the classroom environment was really great, and by the end of the semester I think my yoruba has gotten much better.
Yes I highly recommend taking Yoruba its such a unique and fun learning experience and the professor is very cool very funny guy
